author: By Ilana Kaplan
title: A Scrappy Downtown Radio Station Returns From the Dead, Again
description: Frank Prisinzano and Jorge Parreira have resurrected East Village Radio, an underground institution, after shuttering it roughly a decade ago.
content: Frank Prisinzano has had to mourn the loss of East Village Radio twice over the past 20 years. But ever since it shuttered the second time, in 2014, he has aimed to resurrect it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Picks Maya Rudolph and Jim Gaffigan to Play Kamala Harris and Tim Walz
description: The casting ended months of speculation after President Biden, played on Saturday by Dana Carvey, withdrew from the race. James Austin Johnson continued as Donald Trump.
content: “Saturday Night Live” dug deep into its contact list of celebrity alumni and friends in the comedy world as it kicked off its 50th season with an opening sketch that featured Maya Rudolph’s anticipated return as Vice President Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kelly McMasters
title: Why I Write My Own Obituary Every Year
description: It’s not as maudlin as it might seem. If you take a few minutes to try it, you might find the same.
content: I wrote my obituary last week. I often do so once a year; it has become a kind of ritual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan and Caroline Tompkins
title: Have We Gotten Aubrey Plaza Wrong This Whole Time?
description: Don’t let her deadpan sense of humor fool you. In projects like Francis Ford Coppola’s “Megalopolis,” she puts everything she has on the line.
content: “I bleed for movies,” Aubrey Plaza told me on an August morning, just seconds before the ground began to tremble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Students Paid Thousands for a Caltech Boot Camp. Caltech Didn’t Teach It.
description: Hundreds of universities have lent their names to online programs, plugging budgets but alienating students who feel misled.
content: Raymond Sewer said he had good reason to believe that the California Institute of Technology would be deeply involved in the cloud computing “boot camp.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders, Remy Tumin and Sara Ruberg
title: Georgia Residents Can Return Home After Evacuation During Chemical Plant Fire
description: Tens of thousands of Rockdale County residents were evacuated or sheltering in place as smoke continued to pour out from the site on Monday.
content: Orders to evacuate and shelter-in-place were lifted in Rockdale County, Ga. on Monday night after authorities deemed the environment safe after a chemical plant fire broke out Sunday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Sean Combs’s White Parties Were Edgy, A-List Affairs. Were They More?
description: The events helped the music mogul raise his profile. But one woman who worked at them has said in court papers that the parties had a dark side, too.
content: In the 2000s, few events held the cultural cachet of the White Party thrown by Sean Combs — fetes in Beverly Hills, the Hamptons and other playgrounds of the rich, studded with famous names and fabulous tableaus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: Beneath the Potential Strike at U.S. Ports: Tensions Over Innovation
description: Port operators have long embraced automation, while dockworkers view it as a threat to their livelihoods.
content: Throughout the centuries, as ships have navigated oceans bearing all manner of freight, the companies that operate ports have pressed to limit what they spend on the people who load and unload cargo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 477
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Monday, Sept. 30, 2024.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: Trump Says He’s in Danger. So Why Did He Seek Out the Embrace of 100,000 Fans?
description: After two assassination attempts, the former president seems to be relishing the dangers of his job. Some at the Georgia-Alabama football game wondered if his appearance was wise.
content: Chicken tenders and cynicism were flying through the air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What to Wear Next
description: A brilliant Loewe collection, some good ideas from Courrèges and Junya Watanabe, and a step forward at Alexander McQueen.
content: Finally, a new look.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Drake Hogestyn, ‘Days of Our Lives’ Actor, Dies at 70
description: Mr. Hogestyn was best known for playing John Black on the daytime soap opera and appeared in more than 4,200 episodes over 38 years.
content: Drake Hogestyn, who played John Black, the sturdy and fiercely loyal character who by turns was a spy, private investigator and mercenary, for nearly 40 years on the long-running soap opera “Days of Our Lives,” died on Saturday, a day shy of his 71st birthday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Beller
title: Meet the Star of Sushi-Con: A 400-Pound Tuna
description: At an all-you-can-eat Japanese food expo in Manhattan, thousands lined up to witness the ceremonial carving of an enormous bluefin tuna — and try a sample.
content: “It’s coming! It’s coming!” someone yelled. It was before dawn on a recent Sunday, and a dozen men in matching navy-blue T-shirts were waiting by a loading dock in Manhattan for the headliner of Sushi-Con, which bills itself as the largest expo of Japanese cuisine in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Top Adams Aides Get Married as Investigation Swirls Around Them
description: Eric Adams’s schools chancellor and first deputy mayor married in Martha’s Vineyard this weekend. Both have had their phones seized by federal investigators.
content: At a wedding in Martha’s Vineyard, key players in City Hall sought refuge this weekend from the several federal investigations plaguing Mayor Eric Adams’s administration.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 29, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 29, 2024.
content: An article this weekend on Page 10 about the multilingual singer-songwriter Lhasa de Sela, who will be honored with memorial concerts at Pop Montreal, misstates the title of a Lhasa song. It is “Soon This Space Will Be Too Small,” not “Soon This Place Will Be Too Small.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: The Novelist Who Foresaw the ‘Big One’ for Florida’s Gulf Coast
description: John D. MacDonald was eerily prescient about the risks of human-driven climate disasters in the region.
content: When I learned early Friday morning that Cedar Key, Fla., had been flattened overnight by Hurricane Helene, one of the first things that came to my mind was a song lyric by Jimmy Buffett — early Buffett, before he became a walking tourist attraction. One of his better songs is “Incommunicado,” released in 1981. It begins: “Travis McGee’s still in Cedar Key/That’s what old John MacDonald said.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: A ‘Perfect’ Take on Nantucket Style?
description: Scrutinizing the costumes in Netflix’s “The Perfect Couple.”
content: “It’s not a documentary,” said Signe Sejlund, the costume designer for the Netflix limited series “The Perfect Couple.” “It’s a murder mystery.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Sticky Guava Ribs for Any Season
description: Kia Damon’s recipe is an easy oven-baked barbecue situation that leads to tender meat and a caramelized bark that’s sweet and salty.
content: Good morning. I’d cook outside every night if I could, working grills and planchas and pizza ovens and smokers into the depths of winter, against all elements. I know I’m not alone in that desire. But I know too that the numbers don’t add up to even a plurality. I’m in a faction: the brazier caucus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kiersten White
title: They Have a Sacred Pact With a Bog. It Might Be a Curse.
description: In “The Bog Wife,” a West Virginia family must reckon with secrets, betrayals and the destruction of their legacy when a supernatural covenant that protected them begins to falter.
content: Much like its main characters, Kay Chronister’s new novel, “The Bog Wife,” lives in two worlds at once. It’s situated both in the real world, with fraught familial and marital relationships, complex social dynamics and crucial activities like paying bills and pre-emptively felling dangerous trees, as well as in a dreamy Southern gothic world filled with ancient magic, supernatural compacts and, potentially, murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Eastern Tennessee Officials Brace Residents for ‘Life Lost’ After Helene
description: Though no bodies have been recovered in Unicoi County, authorities say they expect fatalities among about a half-dozen people who remain missing.
content: There has been “life lost” in Tennessee, an emergency official in the state said on Saturday evening, making it the sixth state where people have been killed by Hurricane Helene, which ravaged the Southeast and left more than 50 dead this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Etienne
title: The Question Kamala Harris Needs to Answer to Beat Donald Trump
description: She has prosecuted the case against Donald Trump and clarified some policy views, but not her why. That’s what voters want to know.
content: Kamala Harris is at the halfway point between when she officially became the Democratic presidential nominee and Election Day. Her ascent has been remarkable. She is beating Donald Trump in most national polls and is in statistical dead heats in every battleground state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anderson Tepper
title: Ta-Nehisi Coates on Why Not Everyone Will Love His New Book
description: In “The Message,” Coates grapples with questions about which stories are told, and how, through his visits to Senegal, South Carolina and the West Bank.
content: Ta-Nehisi Coates’s breakthrough memoir, “Between the World and Me,” made an immediate impact when it was published in 2015, at the fraught tail end of the Obama era, and catapulted the Baltimore-born writer to prominence in the public conversation on race. “I’ve been wondering who might fill the intellectual void that plagued me after James Baldwin died,” Toni Morrison declared. “Clearly it is Ta-Nehisi Coates.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Coppola’s ‘Megalopolis’ Plays to Near-Empty Theaters
description: Francis Ford Coppola spent roughly $140 million on the film, which debuted to an estimated $4 million in weekend ticket sales.
content: There is no kind way to put it: Francis Ford Coppola’s “Megalopolis” died on arrival over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clyde McGrady and Eric Lee
title: The Black Church Has a Gen-Z Issue: ‘They Don’t Come Into the Building Anymore’
description: These congregations are struggling to attract younger members. That has consequences for social cohesion and Black political power writ large.
content: On a Sunday morning, about 100 worshipers gathered for services at Mother Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church in Philadelphia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag, Euan Ward and Adam Rasgon
title: Israel Strikes Multiple Fronts, Including Long-Distance Attack on Yemen
description: The escalation of violence between Israel and Iran-backed proxies across the Middle East threatened to bring the combatants closer to an all-out regional war.
content: Israel’s military on Sunday attacked its enemies in two countries and Gaza, including with a long-distance airstrike in Yemen amid escalating violence between Israel and Iranian-backed proxies across the Middle East, inching the combatants closer to an all-out regional war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Desiree Ibekwe
title: Inside the Sally Rooney Fan Base
description: We explore some of the most passionate fans in literature.
content: On Wednesday, a crowd of mostly young women, many carrying bookstore tote bags, filled a venue on the bank of the River Thames. They — we — were there to hear the Irish novelist Sally Rooney discuss “Intermezzo,” her latest novel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,199
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for September 30, 2024.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Netanyahu, Ignoring Allies and Defying Critics, Basks in a Rare Triumph
description: Israel’s strike on Hassan Nasrallah was the culmination of several startling moves that suggest the Israeli prime minister feels unconstrained by foreign criticism.
content: Benjamin Netanyahu’s decision to assassinate Hassan Nasrallah, the Hezbollah leader, capped an increasingly brazen sequence of escalatory moves that reflected the Israeli prime minister’s renewed confidence in Israel’s military strength as well as in his own ability to navigate and defy foreign criticism, analysts said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko, Jan Ransom and Michael Rothfeld
title: In Adams Indictment, Legal Experts See Strengths, Potential Pitfalls
description: Prosecutors pursuing corruption charges against Mayor Eric Adams appear to have some solid evidence, but winning a conviction is far from a given, experts say.
content: For nearly a year, federal prosecutors have closed in on Mayor Eric Adams of New York, seizing his phones and searching the homes of his aides in moves that suggested they might take the extraordinary step of charging him while he still held office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Five People Dead in Plane Crash Near Wright Brothers Memorial
description: A single-engine plane was trying to land when it crashed into a wooded area near the memorial in North Carolina on Saturday, the National Park Service said.
content: Five people were killed after a small plane crashed at an airport in North Carolina on Saturday near the Wright Brothers National Memorial in Kill Devil Hills, the National Park Service said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump’s Answer to Harris’s Border Trip: Calling Her ‘Mentally Disabled’
description: Former President Donald J. Trump assailed Vice President Kamala Harris in harshly personal terms in what he conceded was “a dark speech.”
content: The day after Vice President Kamala Harris visited the southern border and pledged to crack down on asylum and beef up security, former President Donald J. Trump unleashed a string of sharply personal attacks on her at a rally on Saturday, expressing contempt for her intelligence and calling her “mentally disabled.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam and Jonathan Abrams
title: Partying With Sean Combs: Old Stories Gain New Life
description: For decades, Combs and other celebrities have commented on his party lifestyle. Here’s some of what they have publicly said.
content: In 2005, when Sean Combs — also known as Diddy or Puff Daddy — hosted the MTV Video Music Awards, the network advertised the broadcast with a playful star-studded spoof called “Diddy Parties,” in which the events he hosted were referred to as “hedonistic romps.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Enrich
title: A Grieving Mother. A Famous Uncle. An Unlikely Crusade.
description: Tragedy turned Nadia Milleron, Ralph Nader’s niece, into an activist. Now she’s on a long-shot campaign for Congress.
content: Nadia Milleron, an independent candidate for Congress, slipped off her shoes and climbed onto the bench of a picnic table. It was a muggy August evening, and gnats and mosquitoes were swarming the 50 or so people who had gathered for a campaign event in the garden behind a pizzeria in western Massachusetts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Garrison Lovely
title: Laws Need to Catch Up to Artificial Intelligence’s Unique Risks
description: Artificial intelligence poses unique risks, so the people warning us of safety threats deserve unique protections.
content: For about five years, OpenAI used a system of nondisclosure agreements to stifle public criticism from outgoing employees. Current and former OpenAI staff members were paranoid about talking to the press. In May, one departing employee refused to sign and went public in The Times. The company apologized and scrapped the agreements. Then the floodgates opened. Exiting employees began criticizing OpenAI’s safety practices, and a wave of articles emerged about its broken promises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Holmes
title: Tolerating the Office When It Feels Like High School
description: How to stay cordial when your adult colleagues gossip like teenagers.
content: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim, Alexandra Berzon and Nick Corasaniti
title: Trump Allies Bombard the Courts, Setting Stage for Post-Election Fight
description: Republicans are filing a barrage of election lawsuits in the final weeks of the presidential campaign. The cases may be a road map for a legal battle over the results.
content: Republicans have unleashed a flurry of lawsuits challenging voting rules and practices ahead of the November elections, setting the stage for what could be a far larger and more contentious legal battle over the White House after Election Day.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: From ‘Elegant Oakey’ to Adams, City Has a Long and Colorful History of Scandals
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 29, 2024.
content: “You were almost required to be corrupt. The systemic corruption was amazing, yet routine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hilarie M. Sheets
title: The Forgotten Dealer Who Discovered Picasso and Matisse
description: A show at the Grey Art Museum re-establishes Berthe Weill as a guiding light of the Parisian avant-garde. Her rediscovery has been led by women.
content: “A collection of paintings isn’t like a stock portfolio,” the Parisian art dealer Berthe Weill declared in her 1933 memoir, “Pow! Right in the Eye!” She was lamenting that novice collectors of the era were overly concerned about whether the value of her emerging artists would rise. “I was afraid they had neither confidence nor perseverance,” she wrote.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Parsons
title: There’s a Dangerous Misconception About the Military’s Obligations to the President
description: The prospect of a second Trump administration has rekindled an important debate from four years ago.
content: The prospect of a second Trump administration has rekindled a debate from four years ago about the proper role of the military in our democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Opera Is Still Obsessed With the Suffering of Women
description: Two new works, “The Listeners” and “Grounded,” echo the age-old spectacle of female disintegration and show the tension of fitting modern stories into old forms.
content: Opera’s job is to show us what’s bigger, wilder and more intense than ordinary life. It’s a terrarium in which we watch a condensed version of ourselves, with more ecstatic loves and more savage suffering.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 28, 2024
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Sept. 28, 2024.
content: An article this weekend on Page 10 about the multilingual singer-songwriter Lhasa de Sela, who will be honored with memorial concerts at Pop Montreal, misstates the title of a Lhasa song. It is “Soon This Space Will Be Too Small,” not “Soon This Place Will Be Too Small.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Berzon and Nick Corasaniti
title: Five Court Cases to Watch Ahead of Election Day
description: A blizzard of voting lawsuits are landing in swing states in the final weeks before the election. Here’s a guide to the cases that could matter most.
content: While Donald J. Trump and Kamala Harris enter into the final weeks of the presidential campaign, their lawyers are in a final push, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Stellantis, Owner of Chrysler and Jeep, Slashes Profit Forecast
description: The automaker, created by a 2021 merger, is dealing with labor unrest, slumping sales and a revolt from its dealers.
content: Stellantis, an automotive colossus that owns more than a dozen brands including Chrysler, Fiat, Jeep, Peugeot and Ram, is facing challenges at seemingly every turn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Netanyahu Opponent, in Reversal, Is Joining Israeli Government
description: The addition of Gideon Saar to Benjamin Netanyahu’s coalition strengthens the prime minister’s political position.
content: Gideon Saar, a member of Israel’s opposition, announced on Sunday that he would be joining Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s government, giving the Israeli leader’s fragile coalition an added layer of support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Moens
title: California Passes Law Protecting Consumer Brain Data
description: The state extended its current personal privacy law to include the neural data increasingly coveted by technology companies.
content: On Saturday, Governor Gavin Newsom of California signed a new law that aims to protect people’s brain data from being potentially misused by neurotechnology companies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: Ta-Nehisi Coates Returns to the Political Fray, Calling Out Injustice
description: “The Message” marks his re-entry as a public intellectual determined to wield his moral authority, especially regarding Israel and the occupied territories.
content: Ta-Nehisi Coates has returned to the fray. In 2017, after getting into a public dust-up with Cornel West, who accused him of being in thrall to a “neoliberal establishment,” Coates, declaring he “didn’t get in it for this,” summarily deleted his Twitter account. A year later, he left his longtime post as a staff writer at The Atlantic. He spent the next several years far from the combative world of intellectual celebrity and immersed in his own creative projects: writing comics, publishing a novel and working on Hollywood scripts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Why the World’s Biggest Powers Can’t Stop a Middle East War
description: The United States’ ability to influence events in the Mideast has waned, and other major nations have essentially been onlookers.
content: Over almost a year of war in the Middle East, major powers have proved incapable of stopping or even significantly influencing the fighting, a failure that reflects a turbulent world of decentralized authority that seems likely to endure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran’s Leaders Are Vulnerable, Divided and at a Crossroad on Response to Israel
description: Leaders in Tehran suggested it would be the Lebanese militia that would strike back at Israel after the killing of Hassan Nasrallah and bombings in Beirut.
content: In the turbulent landscape of the Middle East, Iran’s aging supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, could always rely on the close alliance, unwavering loyalty and deep friendship of Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of the Lebanese militia Hezbollah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelle Taft, Sara Ruberg, Kate Selig and Elisabeth Parker
title: Helene Has Killed More Than 110 People. Here Are Some of Their Stories.
description: After the Category 4 hurricane made landfall on Florida’s Gulf Coast and pummeled the Southeast, some victims’ portraits were coming into focus.
content: A woman in her 70s who repaired nuclear cooling towers and rode motorcycles. A Florida resident who helped her community recover from Hurricane Ian two years ago. A man who had just moved to South Carolina to work as an electrical lineman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: ‘S.N.L.’ Recap: Maya Rudolph Returns to Play Kamala Harris
description: The 50th season began with several surprise guests and alumni — including Dana Carvey, Jim Gaffigan and Andy Samberg — playing figures in the 2024 election.
content: “Saturday Night Live” dug deep into its contact list of celebrity alumni and friends in the comedy world as it kicked off its 50th season with an opening sketch that featured Maya Rudolph’s anticipated return as Vice President Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: As Austrians Vote, Far Right Awaits Its Biggest Success
description: The Freedom Party has made itself the country’s most popular party, with calls to bar asylum seekers. It is poised to come out on top in parliamentary elections for the first time.
content: He calls himself the “Volkskanzler,” or people’s chancellor, a term associated with the Nazis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Roy
title: Kylie Jenner and Ayo Edebiri Toast a Starry Crowd at Paris Fashion Week
description: Actors, designers and musicians turned out at a party to celebrate the Business of Fashion’s annual index of industry leaders.
content: After a cold and dreary week in Paris, the sun finally broke through on Saturday morning, just in time for the tail end of Paris Fashion Week.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Rape Cases in the Headlines and in Our Everyday Lives
description: Readers discuss a guest essay about famous cases and offer personal stories. Also: Helping immigrants; A.I. at war; Donald Trump, TV and real life.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Israel Strikes the Houthis, an Iranian Ally, in Yemen
description: The strike on power stations and a seaport, which killed four people, was the second known time that Israel has retaliated against the militant group’s attacks by striking in Yemen.
content: The Israeli military conducted airstrikes in Yemen on Sunday after Iranian-backed Houthis there fired three missiles at Israel over the past couple of weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai and Nasuna Stuart-Ulin
title: Studying at an English-Speaking University? In Quebec, That May Cost Extra.
description: Quebec says a new policy to charge some students higher tuition at top universities in Montreal is needed to preserve the province’s French identity.
content: Quebec is working hard to fortify its official language — much to the displeasure of some who don’t speak it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: After Harris Calls for a Crackdown on Fentanyl, Trump Twists Her Position
description: Vice President Kamala Harris vowed to combat the flow of fentanyl into the country when she visited the border on Friday. Former President Donald J. Trump ratcheted up his false claims in response.
content: When Vice President Kamala Harris visited the southern border on Friday, she called fentanyl a “scourge on our country” and said that as president she would “make it a top priority to disrupt the flow of fentanyl coming into the United States.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anand Giridharadas
title: Is Malcolm Gladwell Out of Ideas?
description: In “Revenge of the Tipping Point,” the best-selling author looks back at his old theories.
content: Malcolm Gladwell could have written a fresh book. Instead, he created a brand extension of his 2000 hit, “The Tipping Point.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: What This Israel-Hezbollah-Hamas-Iran Conflict Is Really About
description: The devastating blow to Hezbollah by Israel has a place in the global struggle between the “coalition of inclusion” and “coalition of resistance.” It could be the keystone.
content: To understand why and how Israel’s devastating blow to Hezbollah is such a world-shaking threat to Iran, Russia, North Korea and even China, you have to put it in the context of the wider struggle that has replaced the Cold War as the framework of international relations today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon J. Levien
title: Republicans Criticize Trump Over His Insults of Harris
description: Several Republicans distanced themselves from their party’s standard-bearer after he called Vice President Kamala Harris “mentally disabled.”
content: Former President Donald J. Trump drew criticism from several fellow Republicans on Sunday for his demeaning insults of Vice President Kamala Harris, a day after he called her “mentally disabled” and “mentally impaired” at a rally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: What We Know About Hurricane Helene’s Destruction So Far
description: After hitting Florida’s Gulf Coast, Helene tore through the Southeast and particularly ravaged western North Carolina with floods and mudslides. The overall death toll rose to more than 100.
content: After making landfall as a Category 4 hurricane and tearing through the Gulf Coast of Florida and parts of Georgia last week, Helene left large parts of North Carolina in a state of paralysis over the weekend, washing out roads, causing landslides and knocking out power and cell service for millions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beth Macy
title: I Grew Up Much Like JD Vance. How Did We End Up So Different?
description: The vice-presidential nominee should be thinking of how to extend a ladder to those he left behind, not how to pull it up behind him.
content: I hail from western Ohio, not far from JD Vance’s hometown, Middletown. Like him, I grew up in a family marred by addiction, with a grandmother who was also my rock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall and Clark Hodgin
title: Lie-Flat Seats and Chilled Champagne: Testing Eric Adams’s Upgrade Life
description: The New York mayor is accused of accepting free luxury travel in exchange for political favors. How large was he living? A writer puts the experience to the test.
content: Life is grand in the Bentley Suite at the St. Regis Istanbul, with its marble floors and walk-in closet, its 24-hour butler service, and its views stretching all the way to the blue waters of the Bosporus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Far Right Wins Austrian Vote but May Fall Short of Forming a Government
description: The Freedom Party got nearly 30 percent of the national vote, but mainstream parties have vowed to join in a coalition government without the party’s pugilistic leader, Herbert Kickl.
content: Austrian voters handed the Freedom Party of Austria a solid win in national elections on Sunday, rebuking establishment parties and notching another victory for a xenophobic party in Europe as the tide of far-right populism rises on the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma and Anupreeta Das
title: Nepal Flooding and Landslides Kill at Least 190 People
description: The mountainous country is experiencing more extreme weather driven by climate change, including melting glaciers that add to the frequency and severity of flooding.
content: Police say 193 people have died in Nepal after days of unceasing rain caused heavy flooding and triggered major landslides around the country, including in the densely populated region around Kathmandu, the   capital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Kris Kristofferson, Country Singer, Songwriter and Actor, Dies at 88
description: He wrote songs for hundreds of other artists, including “Me and Bobby McGee” for Janis Joplin and “Sunday Morning Coming Down” for Johnny Cash, before a second act in film.
content: Kris Kristofferson, the singer and songwriter whose literary yet plain-spoken compositions infused country music with rarely heard candor and depth, and who later had a successful second career in movies, died on Saturday at his home on Maui, Hawaii. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Monday Briefing: The Aftermath of Nasrallah’s Death
description: Plus, we retraced one of Mayor Eric Adams’s lavish trips to Istanbul.
content: Hezbollah’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, was killed on Friday near Beirut, Lebanon, in an attack that Israel’s military said had hit the militia’s headquarters. Nasrallah was a beacon for anti-Israel forces across the Middle East and beyond, and his death is a major blow to Hezbollah.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: Vance Criticizes Ukraine’s President a Day After His Meeting With Trump
description: Senator JD Vance of Ohio, former President Donald J. Trump’s running mate, criticized President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine during a campaign rally in Pennsylvania.
content: A day after former President Donald J. Trump met with President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, his running mate, Senator JD Vance of Ohio, criticized the Ukrainian president Saturday during a campaign stop in Pennsylvania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Donald Trump and His Real-Life Apprentice
description: The former president views JD Vance as a kindred political spirit, while Mr. Vance has spoken of Mr. Trump as a kind of father figure.
content: Senator JD Vance has driven some of the most attention-grabbing story lines of the 2024 presidential election, encroaching on the precious spotlight that his running mate, Donald J. Trump, has long kept for himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: On Sports Podcast, Harris Will Discuss Race and Police Brutality
description: A nearly hourlong conversation on “All the Smoke” could help Vice President Kamala Harris reach Black men in the closing weeks of her presidential campaign.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris will discuss racial identity, police brutality and more Monday on the sports and pop culture podcast “All the Smoke,” which is hosted by two retired N.B.A. players.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Dunlap
title: A Capsule of the Past, a Vessel for the Future
description: In 1999, The Times Magazine commissioned a time capsule to be opened at the next millennium. It has been hidden from public view since 2018.
content: On the eve of the new millennium, in 1999, The New York Times Magazine commissioned the celebrated architect Santiago Calatrava to design a time capsule.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Iran Is Losing. That May Matter More Than Israel’s Mistakes.
description: Military success rarely brings true peace, but it can preserve societies.
content: Military defeats matter. Israel’s inexcusable complacency on Oct. 7, 2023, allowed Hamas, a terrorist force with a small fraction of the military strength of the Israel Defense Forces, to kill more Israeli civilians than the vast armies of Egypt and Syria and their allies did at the height of the Arab-Israeli wars of 1967 and 1973.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Tim Arango
title: In North Carolina, Remnants of Helene Become an ‘Unprecedented Tragedy’
description: Thousands of people struggled to cope without basic necessities as authorities searched for the missing, and the overall death toll from the storm surpassed 100.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cecilia Kang
title: California Governor Vetoes Sweeping A.I. Legislation
description: The bill would have been the first in the nation to place strict guardrails on the new technology, but Gov. Gavin Newsom said the bill was flawed.
content: Gov. Gavin Newsom on Sunday vetoed a California artificial intelligence safety bill, blocking the most ambitious proposal in the nation aimed at curtailing the growth of the new technology.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I Was at a Business Lunch at a Well-Regarded Restaurant’
description: A question before ordering, a children’s oasis in Bay Ridge and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bora Erden, June Kim, Elena Shao and Jeremy White
title: Hurricane Helene: Mapping More Than 600 Miles of Devastation
description: See the devastating path carved out by Hurricane Helene from Florida’s Gulf Coast to Tennessee.
content: See the devastating path carved out by Hurricane Helene from Florida’s Gulf Coast to Tennessee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Rebecca Suner, Gabriel Blanco and David Seekamp
title: The Border in the Campaign and in Real Life
description: What do some people who live on the border make of the shifting politics in the battle over their backyard? Astead W. Herndon, a national politics reporter and the host of the politics podcast “The Run-Up,” talked with a group in El Paso, mostly Democrats, and compared what they said and what Americans overall say in polls.
content: What do some people who live on the border make of the shifting politics in the battle over their backyard? Astead W. Herndon, a national politics reporter and the host of the politics podcast “The Run-Up,” talked with a group in El Paso, mostly Democrats, and compared what they said and what Americans overall say in polls.
source.name: The New York Times
